1  13 A BASEBALL FIELD L3 For the briefest of moments, the dreamlike image of a baseball field at night, illuminated by floodlights, flares in over the lawn. Standing on the edge of the field, is the figure of a man with his back to us. Before we can see anything else, the image disappears.

i5 THE MAN AND THE FIELD 1 5 The dream image flares in again, this time closer to the man. He stands in the middle distance, silhouetted by the lights, and we see he is wearing a uniform of some kind.
17 THE MAN  17 Now we see him in head-and-shoulders. He has the muscular neck of an athlete. As he slowly turns we start to see a bit of his weathered face before the image flares out.
family is eating dinner. Ray seems lostin thought.
You're the fella that plowed under your corn and built a baseball diamond, right?
Greatest damn thing I ever heard.
It was like having part of me amputated.

I've heard that old man wake up and scratch itchy legs that've been dust for fifty years. That was me. I'd wake up in the night with the smell of the ballpark in my nose and the cool of the grass on my feet. The thrill of the grass...
Can you pitch?
Not if you can get it near the plate, we don't.
Stick with fast balls, kid.
Damn, this feels good. Put it right here, huh?
Oh man, I did love this game. You know, I'd have played for food money. it was the game, the sounds, the smells. You ever held a glove or a ball to your face?

And it was riding the trains from town to town. And the hotels with brass spittoons in the lobbies and brass beds in the rooms. And it was the crowd getting to their feet when the ball was hit deep. Shoot, I'd have played for free.
What's with the lights?
Makes it harder to see the ball.
Owners...
Joe. Ma'm...
Hi.

Hey! Is this heaven?

See you later, Ray.
Hi, Ray, welcome back.
Pleasure's mine.
Ray, I hope you don't mind, but we got tired of just having practices, so we brought another team out with us so we could have some real games.
Where'd we come from. Man, you wouldn't believe how many guys wanted to play here. We had to beat 'em off with a stick.
With a couple of Cardinals and A's thrown in for good measure. Ty Cobb wanted to play, but none of us could stand the sonofabitch when we were alive, so we told him to stuff it.

Go warm up!

give you a more than a fair price and you walk away with a nest egg.

You have no money, you've got a stack of bills to choke a pig, and come fall, you've got no crop to sell. But I have a deal to offer you that will allow you to stay on this land.
Let us buy you out, and we'll leave the house. You can live in it rent free as long as you want.
Do you realize what this land is worth?
Then you must realize we cannot keep a useless baseball diamond in the middle of rich farmland.
You're virtually bankrupt, and I'm offering you a way to keep your home because I love my sister! I've got partners who don't give a damn about you, and they're ready to foreclose right now!
Karin, please!
You're not listening to this seriously, are you?
Why would anybody pay money to come here?
What the hell is she talking about?
Okay, this is all fascinating, but the fact remains that you don't have the money to bring the mortgage up to date, so you still have to sell. I'm sorry, but you have no choice.
Just sign the papers, Ray.
Listen to me. Tomorrow morning, when the bank opens, they will foreclose.
You're broke, Ray. Sell now or lose everything.
Ray. You will lose everything and you will be evicted.
Don't do this, you son of a bitch!
You're crazy. You're all bat-shit crazy!

And you've turned your daughter into a goddamn moron!

I live. I work. I've learned to cook.

'Moonlight' Graham.

Doctor Graham.

Tell me about his wife.

No screwing, no drinking, no opium, no illegitimate children. No-midnight abortions, no shady finances.

Ray...

game... it's a piece of our past. It reminds us of all that once was good.

You were kidnapping me at the time, you asshole! Think of it, Ray: maybe there's an Ebbets Field still floating around out there somewhere. And maybe I'll get to sit in the stands, and watch a twenty-year-old kid with a smooth face and kinky hair try out for the 1948 Dodgers.
There's something out there for me, Ray.

Game don't start for a while, but you can go in, watch batting practice.
You mean 'Doc' Graham.
Yes, that's Doctor Graham.
His baseball career never amounted to much, so he went back to school. His father was a doctor.
The day he died.
Excuse me.
You might want to talk to some of these people. They knew Doc pretty well.

Oh, that man had an arm on him. One day over at the ballpark, he said 'Lemme see that ball', and one of the boys threw him the ball, and he walked over behind home plate, reared back, and fired that ball over the left field fence.
It was still rising when it disappeared.
And he was at least fifty years old when he did it.
i went with him to make a housecall at one of the camps. .mining camps. The husband was sick, and they had no stove, so they had no heat.
When we got back to Chisholm, Doc went to the hardware store and bought a stove for them and paid to have it delivered.
He didn't smoke or drink, .but he used to chew up paper and spit it out wherever he went. If you were around Doc very long, you learned to duck.
Alicia. She moved to South Carolina after he passed. She passed a few years later. She always wore blue. I bet you didn't know that.
He'd even chew up his prescription slips, so sometimes we'd have to dig into our pockets for a piece of paper so Doc could write us prescriptions.
He always wore a black overcoat, even in the summer, and it was always flapping open, even in the winter and it was fifty below. And he had white hair, like me, and he always carried an umbrella.
Oh, I think it got to be a habit, something to hang onto. But if you'd ask him, he'd say it was to beat away all his lady admirers.
'Cept he was always, I mean always, losing them. Stores 'round town would just lean his umbrella somewhere near the door, and if anybody asked, they'd just say 'Oh, that's Doc's umbrella'.
You know, everybody's talking about you two. Our neighbors came over last night and we just told Doc'Graham stories until after midnight. I even wrote some of them down.

Well, it's funny. It's like all these memories we have of Doc had gone to sleep and sunk way down inside us. But once you started asking about him, and started us talking about him, why they swum back up to the surface again.
Who's that?
No one's called me 'Moonlight' Graham for fifty years.
Funny. I couldn't sleep tonight.
Let's go to the high school. We can sit in my office. What do. you want to talk about?
'Cause of a night like this, long ago.
Anyway, I fell asleep. Next morning, they found me in the on-deck circle, all curled up like a baby. Someone called me 'Moonlight,' and it stuck.
It was the last day of the season.
Nope. They never hit the ball out of the infield.
Heads up.
Anyway, one inning later the game was over, and so was I.
It was like coming this close to your dreams, and then watching them brush past you like a stranger in a crowd.

Except, at the time, you don't think much of it. Hardly anybody recognizes the most significant moment of their life when they're happening. Back then I just figured there'd be plenty more days. I didn't know that would be the only one.
Now, let me ask you a question, Ray Kinsella. What makes that half-inning so interesting that you come all the way from Iowa to ask me about it sixty-five years later?
Ahh...
And are you the kind of man who could grant me that wish?
I never got to bat in the major leagues.
Is there enough magic floating around in the night out there for you to make that wish come true?
I think I might actually believe you.
If it means leaving Chisholm...
This is my most special place in the world, Ray. Once a place touches you like this, the wind never blows so cold again. You feel for it like it was your child. I can't leave here.
It'll stay one. I was born here, lived here, and I'll die here. That's okay.
Son...if I'd only gotten to be a doctor for five minutes. .now that would have been a tragedy.
Well, I'd better get home before Alicia starts to thinking I've got a girlfriend.
What have we got here?
This child's choking to death.
No, son. Thank you.
It's okay...
It's okay.
Well, I best be getting back home before Alicia starts to thinking I've got a girlfriend.

Sure. Watch out-you don't get killed.

He don't want to load the bases. Look for low and away.

We sleep.

Karin!!
Its a twenty-minute drive.
